title: CSS Animations
subject: CSS
theory:
CSS Animations allow you to animate transitions from one CSS style configuration to another.

They consist of two components:
1.  A style describing the CSS animation.
2.  A set of keyframes that indicate the start and end states of the animation's style, as well as possible intermediate waypoints.

examples.explanation: Standard way to create loading spinners.

common_mistakes.correction: If `animation-duration` is not specified, it defaults to 0s, and the animation will not play.

interview_questions.question: Difference between `transition` and `animation`?
interview_questions.answer: Transition requires a trigger (hover, focus, class change) and just goes A to B. Animation works automatically and can have infinite intermediate steps (keyframes) and loop.

practice_problems.problem: Create a pulsing effect (scale up and down) that runs forever.
practice_problems.solution: @keyframes pulse { 0% { transform: scale(1); } 100% { transform: scale(1.1); } } .box { animation: pulse 1s infinite alternate; }

real_world_use_cases.description: Elements fading in and sliding up as you scroll down a landing page.

exam_notes: Keyframes can use words 'from' and 'to' or percentages '0%' and '100%'.
animation-fill-mode: forwards keeps the element in the final state after animation ends.
summary: Keyframe animations bring complex motion design to the web without JavaScript.
